question: Which of the following best represents the role of a coach when a client has a chronic medical condition?

options.A: Diagnose the condition and adjust goals accordingly
options.B: Design a treatment plan using the latest research
options.C: Support the client’s behavior goals and refer as needed
options.D: Provide nutritional counseling specific to the condition

explanations.A: Diagnosis is outside the scope of a health coach. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)
explanations.B: Creating treatment plans is the role of licensed clinicians, not coaches. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.C: Correct. Coaches support clients' behavior goals and refer to licensed professionals when necessary. (NBHWC 1.1, 1.2)
explanations.D: Providing condition-specific nutrition advice requires licensure. (*NBHWC Code of Ethics*)

question: What is the main goal of a coaching session when using Appreciative Inquiry?

options.B: Focus on deficits to develop strategies
options.C: Explore and build on client strengths
options.D: Set SMART goals immediately

explanations.A: Focusing on failure undermines positivity and empowerment. (*Appreciative Inquiry*)
explanations.B: Deficit-based approaches don’t align with Appreciative Inquiry’s strengths-focus. (NBHWC 2.4)
explanations.C: Correct. Appreciative Inquiry builds on what’s working to inspire positive change. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 91)
explanations.D: Goal-setting is important but not the starting point in AI. (NBHWC Coaching Process)

question: A client says, “I don’t have time to cook healthy meals.” What is the best coaching response?

options.A: You really need to prioritize your health.
options.B: Have you considered using a meal delivery service?
options.C: What’s getting in the way of cooking?
options.D: Try batch cooking every Sunday like I do.

explanations.A: This directive comment may feel judgmental and reduce collaboration. (NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.B: Giving advice prematurely misses the chance to explore the root issue. (*Motivational Interviewing*, p. 48)
explanations.C: Correct. Open-ended questioning promotes exploration and client empowerment. (NBHWC Coaching Communication)
explanations.D: Personal stories shift focus away from the client’s unique context. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)

question: Which of the following demonstrates reflective listening?

options.A: You mentioned feeling overwhelmed at work—can you say more?
options.B: Try meditating in the mornings.
options.C: I had the same experience once.
options.D: That’s not as bad as it sounds.

explanations.A: Correct. Reflective listening paraphrases client content and invites deeper sharing. (*Motivational Interviewing*, p. 61; NBHWC 2.1)
explanations.B: This is advice, not reflection. (NBHWC Coaching Communication)
explanations.C: Self-disclosure shifts attention to the coach. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Minimizing a client’s concern is dismissive. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)

question: What strategy best supports a client who is ambivalent about change?

options.B: Use the coach's experience to persuade them
options.C: Explore the pros and cons of changing
options.D: Ask for a commitment to change immediately

explanations.A: Challenging resistance increases defensiveness. (*MI*, p. 83)
explanations.B: Coach experience is less relevant than the client’s perspective. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.C: Correct. Exploring decisional balance helps resolve ambivalence. (*Changing to Thrive*, p. 76; NBHWC 2.3)
explanations.D: Pushing for action too soon can create resistance. (*Motivational Interviewing*)

question: A coach feels emotionally triggered by a client's story. What is the best response?

options.A: Tell the client about your similar experience
options.B: Take a deep breath and remain present
options.C: Redirect the conversation quickly
options.D: End the session early to regroup

explanations.A: Sharing personal stories risks shifting focus. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)
explanations.B: Correct. Centering yourself while staying present supports client-centered care. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 88)
explanations.C: Avoiding the issue may erode trust. (NBHWC Coaching Presence)
explanations.D: Abruptly ending the session may harm rapport. (*MI*)

question: Which of the following is an example of a process goal?

options.B: Eat more vegetables at dinner each night
options.C: Have lower cholesterol next year
options.D: Reduce BMI to 24

explanations.A: Outcome goal—focuses on result, not behavior. (NBHWC Goal Setting)
explanations.B: Correct. A process goal reflects a repeatable behavior. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 133)
explanations.C: Outcome goal tied to a biomarker. (*Changing to Thrive*)
explanations.D: BMI is a result, not a specific action. (NBHWC 2.4)

question: What is the purpose of the 'evoking' phase in Motivational Interviewing?

options.B: To suggest possible plans
options.C: To elicit the client’s own motivations
options.D: To identify resistance and correct it

explanations.A: Summarizing occurs throughout but is not the goal of evoking. (*MI*, p. 92)
explanations.B: Planning comes after motivation is clarified. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.C: Correct. Evoking draws out client reasons for change. (*MI*, p. 92; NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.D: Correcting resistance is counter to MI’s collaborative approach. (*Motivational Interviewing*)

question: What should a coach do when a client repeatedly asks for dietary advice that falls outside their scope?

options.B: Refer to a licensed dietitian
options.C: Tell them what has worked for others
options.D: Give the best answer based on online sources

explanations.A: General tips may still violate scope depending on specificity. (NBHWC Scope)
explanations.B: Correct. Coaches must refer clients when requests exceed legal or ethical boundaries. (NBHWC 1.2, Scope of Practice)
explanations.C: Client anecdotes aren't evidence-based. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Internet-based recommendations are not appropriate. (*NBHWC Code of Ethics*)

question: What is a sign that a client may be in the preparation stage of change?

options.A: They deny any need for change
options.B: They express a desire but no plan
options.C: They set a start date and explore strategies
options.D: They maintain changes over six months

explanations.A: Denial aligns more with precontemplation. (*Changing to Thrive*)
explanations.B: This describes the contemplation stage. (NBHWC Stages of Change)
explanations.C: Correct. Preparation includes intention and early planning. (*Changing to Thrive*, p. 81)
explanations.D: Maintenance involves sustaining behaviors. (NBHWC 2.1)

question: A client says, “I always mess up after a few days.” What is the best coaching response?

options.A: Why do you think that happens?
options.B: It sounds like you’re frustrated—what’s worked before?
options.C: Maybe this goal is too hard for you.
options.D: Let’s try something easier instead.

explanations.A: Asking 'why' may feel confrontational. (NBHWC Coaching Communication)
explanations.B: Correct. Reflects emotion and invites solution-focused dialogue. (*MI*, p. 63)
explanations.C: This risks undermining self-efficacy. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Shifting the goal without exploration may ignore deeper issues. (NBHWC 2.3)

question: Which of the following is most important when co-creating an action plan?

options.A: Ensuring the plan includes at least three steps
options.B: Making sure the client agrees to do it
options.C: Aligning the plan with the client’s values and readiness
options.D: Using a template for goal setting

explanations.A: The number of steps isn’t as important as relevance and achievability. (NBHWC 2.4)
explanations.B: Agreement is key, but deeper alignment with values increases success. (*Changing to Thrive*)
explanations.C: Correct. Value alignment and readiness support intrinsic motivation. (*MI*, p. 85)
explanations.D: Templates may help structure but don’t replace personalized plans. (NBHWC Goal Setting)

question: A coach observes that the client’s tone has changed while discussing a new strategy. What is the best response?

options.B: What’s going on? You sound different.
options.C: I noticed your tone changed—what’s going on for you?
options.D: This strategy might not be right for you.

explanations.A: Avoiding the moment may miss an opportunity for insight. (NBHWC Coaching Presence)
explanations.B: Confrontational tone can reduce openness. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.C: Correct. This is a nonjudgmental observation inviting deeper reflection. (*MI*, p. 66)
explanations.D: Assuming the strategy is wrong without client input is premature. (NBHWC 2.1)

question: A client says, 'I feel so stuck lately.' What coaching technique is most helpful?

options.B: Ask what being stuck feels like to them
options.C: Tell them this is a normal phase
options.D: Offer several options to move forward

explanations.A: May bypass the client’s emotional experience. (NBHWC Coaching Communication)
explanations.B: Correct. Exploring emotions builds awareness and client ownership. (*MI*, p. 71)
explanations.C: Minimizing emotions can reduce trust. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Problem-solving too soon can shut down exploration. (NBHWC 2.2)

question: What is an appropriate action when a client presents with disordered eating behaviors?

options.A: Refer the client to a licensed mental health or medical provider
options.B: Provide mindfulness exercises for body awareness
options.C: Recommend a food journal for tracking
options.D: Coach them to follow intuitive eating principles

explanations.A: Correct. Disordered eating requires licensed care. Referral is appropriate. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)
explanations.B: Mindfulness may help, but only under supervision of a licensed provider. (*NBHWC Ethics*)
explanations.C: Tracking can worsen symptoms if not clinically guided. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Intuitive eating may be therapeutic, but prescribing it is beyond coaching scope. (NBHWC 1.2)

question: What principle underlies the 'affirming' technique in Motivational Interviewing?

options.B: Recognizing client strengths and efforts
options.C: Evaluating client success
options.D: Praising achievement outcomes

explanations.A: Correction is not aligned with MI's collaborative spirit. (*Motivational Interviewing*, p. 55)
explanations.B: Correct. Affirming highlights effort and strengths to boost self-efficacy. (NBHWC 2.3, *MI*)
explanations.C: Evaluation shifts focus from collaboration to judgment. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: MI focuses more on process than outcome praise. (NBHWC Coaching Process)

question: What is the coach’s ethical obligation when working with a client who wants to stop taking prescribed medication?

options.B: Refer them back to their prescribing physician
options.C: Recommend alternatives like supplements
options.D: Tell them to continue until they feel ready

explanations.A: Medication decisions are medical, not coaching, territory. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)
explanations.B: Correct. Coaches must refer to the appropriate provider. (NBHWC 1.2, Scope of Practice)
explanations.C: Supplement advice requires licensure or training. (*NBHWC Scope*)
explanations.D: This could delay necessary medical care. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)

question: Which of the following best supports building a client’s self-efficacy?

options.A: Focusing on what hasn’t worked before
options.B: Encouraging the client to try multiple goals at once
options.C: Celebrating small wins and past efforts
options.D: Reminding them of your expertise

explanations.A: Dwelling on failure reduces confidence. (NBHWC 2.3)
explanations.B: Too many goals can overwhelm and reduce success. (*Changing to Thrive*)
explanations.C: Correct. Recognizing progress reinforces confidence. (*MI*, p. 65; NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.D: Emphasizing coach expertise undermines client autonomy. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)

question: How does a coach maintain presence when feeling distracted during a session?

options.B: Take a breath and refocus on the client
options.C: Let the client lead without further input
options.D: Shift to note-taking to stay engaged

explanations.A: Disclosure may disrupt rapport. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.B: Correct. Self-regulation allows the coach to re-center without interrupting flow. (NBHWC Coaching Presence)
explanations.C: Disengaging may cause the client to feel unsupported. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.D: Note-taking can distract further from active listening. (*MI*, p. 61)

question: Which coaching approach is most appropriate when a client is in the maintenance stage of change?

options.A: Focus on barriers and reasons for failure
options.B: Help the client build relapse-prevention strategies
options.C: Push for new goals immediately
options.D: Decrease session frequency without asking

explanations.A: Dwelling on problems may not support ongoing change. (*Changing to Thrive*)
explanations.B: Correct. Maintenance involves sustaining behavior and preparing for setbacks. (NBHWC 2.4; *MI*)
explanations.C: New goals may distract from current successes. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Session changes should be client-led. (NBHWC Coaching Agreement)

question: A coach begins a session by asking, “What would make today’s conversation meaningful for you?” This is an example of:

options.B: Coaching presence
options.C: Goal setting
options.D: Evaluative feedback

explanations.A: Correct. This question helps co-create the session focus with the client. (NBHWC 2.1)
explanations.B: Presence supports connection but doesn’t structure the session. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.C: Goal setting is more specific to behavior or outcome goals. (NBHWC 2.4)
explanations.D: Feedback comes later in the session and typically involves progress review. (*MI*)

question: Which technique would be least effective in resolving ambivalence?

options.B: Using affirmations
options.C: Telling the client what to do
options.D: Exploring client values

explanations.A: Decisional balance allows clients to weigh pros and cons. (NBHWC 2.3, *Changing to Thrive*)
explanations.B: Affirmations support client confidence. (*Motivational Interviewing*)
explanations.C: Correct. Directing the client can increase resistance. (NBHWC Coaching Communication)
explanations.D: Values exploration helps clarify motivation. (*MI*, p. 85)

question: A client says, “I’ve tried everything and nothing works.” What is a helpful coaching response?

options.A: Maybe this just isn’t the right time.
options.B: Tell me more about what you’ve tried.
options.C: Let’s brainstorm new strategies.
options.D: I know something that might help.

explanations.A: This may reinforce defeatist thinking. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.B: Correct. This open-ended reflection promotes exploration. (*MI*, p. 61)
explanations.C: Brainstorming may be premature before understanding the issue. (NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.D: Providing advice may not empower the client. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)

question: Which of the following would most help a coach maintain boundaries?

options.A: Allowing clients to text anytime for accountability
options.B: Setting clear expectations at the start of the relationship
options.C: Responding to client concerns as they arise
options.D: Sharing personal experiences regularly

explanations.A: 24/7 access may blur professional lines. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)
explanations.B: Correct. Clear expectations foster ethical and sustainable boundaries. (NBHWC 1.1, Coaching Agreement)
explanations.C: Responsiveness is helpful but not sufficient without agreed boundaries. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Frequent self-disclosure can shift focus off the client. (*MI*)

question: Which question best supports visioning with a client?

options.A: Why haven’t you achieved this already?
options.B: What might your life look like if this change happened?
options.C: What is the first step to change?
options.D: How can I help you get started?

explanations.A: ‘Why’ questions can feel judgmental. (*MI*, p. 77)
explanations.B: Correct. Visioning expands possibilities and engages intrinsic motivation. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 91)
explanations.C: This focuses on planning rather than visioning. (NBHWC 2.4)
explanations.D: Shifts attention from client to coach instead of fostering self-direction. (NBHWC Coaching Communication)

question: Which of the following demonstrates a growth mindset?

options.A: I’m just not good at sticking to routines.
options.B: If I fail, that means I’m not ready.
options.C: Mistakes help me figure out what works.
options.D: I need to be perfect to succeed.

explanations.A: Fixed mindset statements limit belief in change. (*Carol Dweck, Mindset*)
explanations.B: Equating failure with inability is a fixed mindset. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.C: Correct. Embracing mistakes as learning opportunities reflects a growth mindset. (*Positive Psychology*)
explanations.D: Perfectionism inhibits progress and confidence. (NBHWC 2.3)

question: Which best defines scope of practice for a health coach?

options.B: Creating exercise prescriptions
options.C: Supporting lifestyle behavior change and referring as needed
options.D: Providing meal plans

explanations.A: Diagnosis is beyond a coach’s training and licensing. (NBHWC Scope)
explanations.B: Exercise prescriptions require credentialing (e.g., ACSM-CPT). (*NBHWC Ethics*)
explanations.C: Correct. Coaches guide behavior change and refer to licensed professionals when needed. (NBHWC 1.1)
explanations.D: Meal planning is typically restricted to dietitians. (*Scope of Practice*)

question: A client reports increased blood pressure. What is the appropriate coaching response?

options.A: Advise them to cut sodium and increase potassium.
options.B: Suggest daily cardio exercise.
options.C: Refer them to their healthcare provider.
options.D: Recommend relaxation supplements.

explanations.A: Offering nutritional advice for medical issues is outside scope. (*NBHWC Scope*)
explanations.B: Exercise suggestions tied to diagnosis require medical clearance. (ACSM Guidelines)
explanations.C: Correct. Medical symptoms warrant referral. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)
explanations.D: Supplement recommendations fall under licensed practitioners. (*NBHWC Ethics*)

question: A coach wants to evaluate the effectiveness of their coaching. What is the most ethical and useful approach?

options.A: Ask clients to share only positive feedback
options.B: Gather anonymous client surveys on outcomes and experience
options.C: Review social media reviews
options.D: Ask clients to post testimonials online

explanations.A: Only positive feedback limits learning and misrepresents outcomes. (NBHWC Ethics)
explanations.B: Correct. Anonymous feedback promotes honesty and program improvement. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.C: Public reviews may not reflect the full coaching experience. (NBHWC 1.1)
explanations.D: Testimonials may be helpful but are not comprehensive evaluation tools. (*NBHWC Scope*)

question: A coach notices a client often self-criticizes. What intervention is most aligned with a coaching approach?

options.B: Challenge their negative thinking directly
options.C: Teach them cognitive restructuring
options.D: Recommend self-help books on mindset

explanations.A: Correct. Encouraging self-kindness promotes resilience and growth. (*Positive Psychology*, NBHWC 2.3)
explanations.B: Challenging thoughts can feel confrontational and is more therapeutic. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.C: Cognitive restructuring is a therapeutic tool outside coach scope. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)
explanations.D: Book suggestions can help but don’t directly shift patterns. (NBHWC Coaching Process)

question: During a coaching session, a client reports they’re sleeping only 4 hours a night and feeling exhausted. What is the best next step?

options.B: Refer them to a licensed healthcare provider
options.C: Encourage more exercise during the day
options.D: Share a guided meditation app

explanations.A: Sleep routines may help, but this level of sleep deprivation is a clinical concern. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)
explanations.B: Correct. Sleep issues with significant impairment warrant referral. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)
explanations.C: Exercise could help but may worsen fatigue without medical guidance. (*ACSM Guidelines*)
explanations.D: Apps may support sleep, but not replace clinical evaluation. (NBHWC 1.1)

question: A client consistently cancels sessions last minute. What is the most appropriate coach response?

options.A: Charge a fee to discourage this behavior
options.B: Ask if the coaching structure still fits their needs
options.C: Remind them of the importance of showing up
options.D: Reduce coaching frequency without asking

explanations.A: Fees can be a boundary but should be discussed in advance. (*NBHWC Coaching Agreement*)
explanations.B: Correct. Exploring fit supports autonomy and respectful engagement. (NBHWC 2.1)
explanations.C: This can sound judgmental and reduce trust. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Adjusting structure without discussion undermines collaboration. (NBHWC 2.2)

question: What is the primary role of a health coach during the goal-setting process?

options.A: Ensure goals are SMART and medically appropriate
options.B: Help clients choose goals aligned with their values and readiness
options.C: Motivate clients to take on ambitious challenges
options.D: Set goals based on health risk factors

explanations.A: SMART goals are helpful, but medical suitability is outside coach scope. (NBHWC Scope)
explanations.B: Correct. Values and readiness are central to sustainable goal setting. (NBHWC 2.4, *MI*)
explanations.C: Ambition without readiness can reduce follow-through. (*Changing to Thrive*)
explanations.D: Coaches do not prescribe risk-based goals. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)

question: When is it most appropriate to offer resources or educational content to a client?

options.A: Only if the client requests it
options.B: After asking permission and confirming interest
options.C: Any time the coach feels it would help
options.D: At the end of each session

explanations.A: Clients may not know what to ask for. Offering with consent is more supportive. (*MI*)
explanations.B: Correct. Asking permission respects autonomy and invites engagement. (NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.C: Unsolicited advice can disrupt rapport. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Timing is based on relevance, not session closure. (NBHWC Coaching Communication)

question: A client says, 'I know I should eat better, but I just don’t care anymore.' What is the best coach response?

options.B: You know it’s important—what’s stopping you?
options.C: Sounds like something has shifted. Want to talk about it?
options.D: Let’s focus on what you should do instead.

explanations.A: ‘Why’ can feel judgmental. (*MI*, p. 61)
explanations.B: This may provoke defensiveness. (NBHWC Coaching Communication)
explanations.C: Correct. This reflects emotion and invites reflection. (*MI*, p. 72)
explanations.D: Shifting to action too quickly can overlook important emotional insight. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)

question: What is the main goal of using open-ended questions in coaching?

options.B: To guide the client toward the right answer
options.C: To explore the client’s inner experience and foster autonomy
options.D: To evaluate the client’s motivation level

explanations.A: Open-ended questions often expand conversation, not shorten it. (NBHWC Coaching Communication)
explanations.B: Coaching is non-directive. Leading questions limit autonomy. (*MI*, p. 53)
explanations.C: Correct. Open-ended questions invite reflection and support self-direction. (NBHWC 2.2)
explanations.D: Evaluation is secondary to exploration in coaching conversations. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)

question: A coach wants to improve their ability to notice and name client strengths. What skill is most relevant?

options.B: Practicing affirmations
options.C: Using closed-ended questions
options.D: Leading goal-setting

explanations.A: Diagnosis is beyond scope. Coaches observe, not label. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)
explanations.B: Correct. Affirmations help reinforce client strengths and confidence. (*MI*, p. 70)
explanations.C: Closed-ended questions limit exploration. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Goal setting follows, not precedes, strength recognition. (NBHWC 2.4)

question: How can a coach support a client struggling with self-doubt?

options.A: Tell them you believe in them
options.B: Ignore the doubt and push forward
options.C: Ask what has helped in the past when they felt confident
options.D: Give them a motivational quote

explanations.A: Supportive, but external validation may not build internal confidence. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.B: Ignoring emotion can create resistance. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.C: Correct. Past successes can reinforce self-efficacy. (*MI*, p. 63; NBHWC 2.3)
explanations.D: Quotes may inspire, but they don’t replace client-led insight. (*Positive Psychology*)

question: Which coaching response best demonstrates reflective listening?

options.B: Sounds like you’re feeling hopeful and a bit nervous.
options.C: You should try journaling that.
options.D: What’s the next step?

explanations.A: This is praise, not reflection. (*MI*, p. 71)
explanations.B: Correct. Reflection captures both emotion and tone. (NBHWC Coaching Communication)
explanations.C: Offering advice redirects ownership. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: Forward planning bypasses emotional acknowledgment. (NBHWC 2.2)

question: What’s the most ethical approach when a client asks the coach for a supplement recommendation?

options.A: Give them a list of options with dosages
options.B: Suggest what has worked for you
options.C: Let them know that’s outside your scope and suggest they speak with a licensed provider
options.D: Tell them to look up reviews online

explanations.A: Prescribing or suggesting dosages is beyond coaching scope. (NBHWC Ethics)
explanations.B: Personal anecdotes can confuse the professional boundary. (*NBHWC Code of Ethics*)
explanations.C: Correct. Referring to a qualified professional maintains ethical integrity. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)
explanations.D: Online sources vary in credibility; referral is safer and more ethical. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)

question: According to CDC guidelines, what is the recommended amount of moderate-intensity exercise per week for adults?

options.B: 90 minutes
options.C: 150 minutes
options.D: 210 minutes

explanations.A: Too low. CDC recommends more for significant health benefits. (CDC Physical Activity Guidelines)
explanations.B: Still below minimum CDC recommendation. (*CDC.gov*)
explanations.C: Correct. The CDC recommends at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity weekly. (*CDC Guidelines*)
explanations.D: Above the minimum; while beneficial, it is not the baseline guideline. (CDC Physical Activity Recommendations)

question: A client expresses fear of failure. What coaching approach best supports them?

options.B: Encourage them to ignore their fear and move forward
options.C: Explore past successes and how they overcame fear
options.D: Advise them to push through regardless

explanations.A: Invalidating fear may harm trust. (*MI*, p. 65)
explanations.B: Avoiding emotional content ignores the client’s experience. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.C: Correct. Highlighting strengths and past resilience supports self-efficacy. (NBHWC 2.3, *Positive Psychology*)
explanations.D: This directive approach undermines autonomy. (NBHWC Coaching Process)

question: A client has a medically supervised diet plan. How should the coach support them?

options.A: Suggest modifications based on client preferences
options.B: Review and explain the meal plan
options.C: Support behavior change and refer questions to the provider
options.D: Encourage skipping parts that feel restrictive

explanations.A: Modifying plans created by a licensed provider is outside scope. (*NBHWC Scope of Practice*)
explanations.B: Interpreting meal plans can be considered medical nutrition therapy. (NBHWC Ethics)
explanations.C: Correct. Coaches support implementation and refer back to providers. (NBHWC 1.1, Coaching Process)
explanations.D: Undermining medical advice is unethical. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)

question: What is a key principle of Appreciative Inquiry?

options.B: Encourage clients to avoid failure
options.C: Explore what gives life to the client when they are most alive
options.D: Identify negative patterns and break them

explanations.A: Appreciative Inquiry focuses on strengths, not fixing. (*Appreciative Inquiry*, Cooperrider)
explanations.B: Avoidance is not a core value of this model. (NBHWC Coaching Philosophy)
explanations.C: Correct. AI invites clients to explore peak experiences and sources of energy. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*, p. 101)
explanations.D: This language aligns more with problem-based approaches. (*Positive Psychology*)

question: Which is an example of a complex reflection?

options.B: You’ve started walking and it seems like you’re proud of yourself for sticking to it.
options.C: You like walking.
options.D: So, you’re exercising.

explanations.A: This is a simple reflection (paraphrasing). (*MI*, p. 71)
explanations.B: Correct. Complex reflections add emotional depth and meaning. (NBHWC Coaching Communication, *MI*)
explanations.C: This reflects content but not feeling or nuance. (*MI*, p. 73)
explanations.D: This is a basic summary. (*MI*)

question: What is a red flag indicating a coach may be working outside their scope?

options.B: Helping a client build motivation
options.C: Interpreting lab test results
options.D: Exploring values and goals

explanations.A: This is a core coaching function. (NBHWC 2.4)
explanations.B: Motivation-building is within scope. (*MI*, p. 55)
explanations.C: Correct. Interpreting labs is a clinical activity for licensed providers. (NBHWC Scope of Practice)
explanations.D: Values exploration is essential in coaching. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)

question: When a client experiences success, what is the best coach response?

options.A: Move on to the next issue
options.B: Congratulate them and suggest a new challenge
options.C: Celebrate the success and ask what made it work
options.D: Remind them there is still work to do

explanations.A: This may miss an opportunity to reinforce progress. (NBHWC Coaching Process)
explanations.B: New challenges can wait—savoring builds motivation. (*Positive Psychology*)
explanations.C: Correct. Reflection on success builds learning and reinforces strengths. (*MI*, *Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.D: This diminishes the moment and can feel discouraging. (NBHWC 2.3)

question: How should a coach respond if a client discloses suicidal thoughts?

options.A: Provide emotional support and continue the session
options.B: Encourage the client to journal about their feelings
options.C: End the session and refer to a mental health professional immediately
options.D: Offer mindfulness techniques

explanations.A: Staying in session delays critical help. (NBHWC Code of Ethics)
explanations.B: Journaling may help, but this is a crisis requiring referral. (*NBHWC Scope*)
explanations.C: Correct. Coaches must refer immediately in crisis situations. (NBHWC Ethics, Scope of Practice)
explanations.D: Mindfulness is not a substitute for urgent mental health care. (*NBHWC Coaching Limits*)

question: A client says, 'I failed again this week.' What is a coaching-aligned response?

options.B: Why do you keep failing?
options.C: Sounds like a tough week. Want to talk about what got in the way?
options.D: Let’s try a more rigid plan.

explanations.A: Shaming reduces motivation. (*MI*)
explanations.B: ‘Why’ can trigger defensiveness. (*Coaching Psychology Manual*)
explanations.C: Correct. This empathetic reflection opens a safe space for exploration. (NBHWC 2.2, *MI*, p. 60)
explanations.D: Rigid plans reduce autonomy and increase resistance. (NBHWC Coaching Process)

question: What distinguishes the Preparation stage in the Transtheoretical Model?

options.B: No intention to change
options.C: Intent to take action in the near future
options.D: Maintenance of new behaviors

explanations.A: This describes Precontemplation. (*Changing to Thrive*)
explanations.B: Also Precontemplation. (*TTM Model*)
explanations.C: Correct. Preparation includes planning to act in the next 30 days. (*Changing to Thrive*, NBHWC 2.4)
explanations.D: Maintenance comes after action is sustained. (*TTM*)
